name: Javan Leopard
description: One of the smallest and rarest subspecies of the clouded leopard, many Javan leopards exhibit black coloration instead of the typical spotted pattern. This innate variation, known as melanism, also occurs in other cat species like jaguars or servals. The solid black appearance is deceptive, as the underlying pattern becomes visible under certain angles of light.
image_alt: Javan leopard, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 1.4–1.5 m; tail length 60–70 cm; shoulder height 45–60 cm; weight 23–40 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 3 months, typically giving birth to 2–3 cubs.
attractions: Like most big cats, it lives a solitary life. It’s most active in the morning and evening, heading out to hunt. Outside these times, it hides in dense undergrowth or the canopies of low trees.
breeding: The male Arjuna arrived at the zoo in 2013 from Tierpark Berlin, where he was born in January 2012.
